p:
Network-based approaches take into account the interactions between different regions. However, the contact network
G
is unknown (and consequently also the infection probability matrix
B
) and must be inferred from the epidemic outbreak. The Network Inference-based Prediction Algorithm (NIPA) was originally proposed in Prasse and Van Mieghem (2020a), and we applied an adaption of NIPA to the spread of COVID-19 in Hubei, China ( Prasse, Achterberg, Ma et al., 2020) and Italy ( Pizzuti, Socievole, Prasse, & Van Mieghem, 2020). NIPA consists of two steps. First, the underlying infection matrix
B
is inferred from the epidemic outbreak. Second, the infection matrix
B
and the estimated curing rates
δ
i
for every node
i
are used to forecast the outbreak by iterating the Susceptible-Infected-Removed (SIR) model on the estimated infection matrix
B
. Even though NIPA successfully forecasted the spread of COVID-19 in the Chinese province Hubei, the underlying infection matrix
B
cannot be inferred ( Prasse & Van Mieghem, 2020b).
